DOC.HEAD: Old-Time Communists Gather to Revive Party
With AM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 800 aging, old-time Communists reaffirmed their loyalty to a hard-line ideology Sunday at a meeting to reorganize the party, which reformers disbanded two months ago. Communist reformers declared the old party dead on Oct. 8 and formed the Hungarian Socialist Party. Former general secretary Karoly Grosz denounced the move as a ``coup.'' Grosz and other leading conservatives since have tried to reassemble like-minded Communists, asserting that the old party _ officially known as the Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party _ still exists. The tone of Sunday's session was set by Gyoergy Marosan, 82, who told the gathering in a voice choked with emotion: ``I am glad I don't have to begin by saying `ladies and Gentlemen' because we are all comrades here.'' The delegates responded with deafening applause. The old Communist Party had more than 750,000 members and they have not been allowed to join the new party unless they sign a declaration reflecting support for democratic reforms similar to those taking place in other Eastern European countries. Marosan urged efforts to avoid ``fratricide,'' referring to the split. ``No one can sweep Marxism off the table of history,'' he told the cheering audience. In his keynote speech, Grosz declared that the Communist Party ``is alive because members want it that way'' and said it had about 100,000 members. He attacked the new government's economic plans, which are similar to his when he was premier 18 months ago, and warned against ``capitalist restoration.'' Grosz announced that the committee that organized the conservatives was resigning and urged the delegates to elect ``new faces, new personalities into the leadership.'' That organizing committee had been an uneasy alliance of former government leaders. It included former Communist ideologist Janos Berecz, one-time Foreign Minister Frigyes Puja and Robert Ribanszki, a former personal secretary of the late party chief Janos Kadar. A strong candidate to lead the party is Gyula Thuermer, Grosz's former foreign policy adviser.
